properties.field_incident_overview:
The Crown Creek Fire began on August 29, 2025, following lightning strikes in Stevens County, northeastern Washington. Burning through a mix of grass, brush, and timber in rugged terrain, the fire grew quickly, forcing multiple evacuation levels for nearby communities. By early September, the fire had expanded to several thousand acres, threatening homes, powerlines, property, and livestock. State mobilization was authorized on August 31, bringing in additional resources and strike teams to support local districts/agencies actively involved in initial attack suppression efforts.

At its peak, the fire reached over 14,000 acres. Thanks to favorable weather, aggressive firefighting efforts, and coordination with cooperators, containment steadily increased to more than 90 percent by the end of September. While mop-up, hazard tree removal, and suppression repair continue, officials remain alert to interior hotspots and lingering smoke impacts. The Crown Creek Fire has underscored both the challenges of rapid fire growth in mixed fuels and the importance of strong interagency coordination in protecting local communities. Over the duration of the fire, multiple incident management teams worked toward containment of the fire and implement suppression repair.

Evacuations: All evacuations were lifted on Sept 23, 2025. Stevens County Interactive Evacuation Map is available and allows users to enter their address to identify if they may be impacted by an incident. Information may also be provided on the Stevens County Emergency Management Facebook page as needed.

Emergency Notifications: It is recommend that all residents in the area sign up for emergency notifications through Hyper-Reach for when a future incident occurs. Hyper-reach is Stevens County’s emergency alert system. It provides rapid notification of hazardous and urgent situations through the use of phone calls, texting and email messages. TTY/TDD service is also available for the hearing impaired.
properties.title: Crown Creek Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Wildfire
properties.field_incident_overview:
The Wildcat Fire was started by lightning in the William O. Douglas Wilderness and was first reported on Monday, August 25, 2025. It grew slowly until Saturday, August 30, when winds caused increased fire activity, with the fire spotting and flanking. Two helicopters and 4 scooper airtanker aircraft dropped water on the fire. Scoopers dipped water out of Bumping Lake. Fire crews scouted for opportunities to go direct on the 28th and 29th. Increased fire activity on Saturday did not allow this effort to continue. 

Firefighters were challenged with hot and dry conditions, which fueled fire growth. Complex Incident Management NW Team 10 assumed command of the fire on September 3, 2025. On September 16, 2025, the fire was returned to a Type 3 IMT team. The SEWAIMT Team 1 took command of the fire at 0600 on Tuesday, Sep 16, 2025. On September 29, 2025 command of the Wildcat Fire was transferred to a local Type 3 Team.  

Due to extreme fire activity and spread, the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest updated its road, trail and area closure (9/2/25). See the complete order and a map under the "Closures" tab on this site.

Yakima County increased the evacuation level for Goose Prairie and Bumping River Road residents to a LEVEL 2 GET SET.
properties.title: Wildcat Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Katy Creek Fire started on August 30, 2025, following lightning strikes in the Colville National Forest, northwest of Kettle Falls, Washington. Burning in steep, rocky terrain with heavy timber, the fire posed challenges for direct suppression and required extensive use of hand crews and aerial resources. Early growth reached several hundred acres within days, ultimately expanding to nearly 4,700 acres. The fire threatened nearby structures and prompted road closures and area restrictions to protect public safety. Fire behavior ranged from smoldering and creeping to isolated torching and spotting under dry, windy conditions. Containment steadily increased as crews conducted mop-up, firing operations, and hazard tree mitigation, with the fire reported at over 90 percent contained in late September. Managed in coordination with other regional incidents, the Katy Creek Fire highlighted both the difficulty of firefighting in rugged forest terrain and the effectiveness of coordinated interagency response.

Closures: Colville National Forest initially implemented a closure order for the Katy Creek Fire but reduced the size on Sept 23, 2025.  View the entire order and map on their website.

Evacuations: Ferry County Sheriff's Office lifted all evacuations on Sept 26, 2025. You can get futures alerts about emergencies and other important community news by signing up for the Ferry County Alert System. You will receive time-sensitive messages wherever you specify, such as your home, mobile, or business phones, email address, text messages, and more.
properties.title: Katy Creek

properties.field_incident_overview:
Public and firefighter safety remain the top priority. Please respect area closures and exercise caution when recreating near the fire. Expect heavier road traffic along ID Hwy 6, FS-768, and FS-1423 as crews move to and from the incident. 

NOTE: Giant White Pine Campground and Laird Park Campground are both currently closed to the public due to the close proximity to this fire and the evolving need to accommodate incoming firefighting personnel.

This page is no longer being updated daily.
properties.title: White Pine

properties.field_incident_overview: The Root Fire was discovered September 1, 2025 north of Castle Creek and west of Castella.  Law enforcement officers from the Forest Service have determined that the Root Fire was caused by an escaped campfire. The fire is burning in Timber understory and grass in steep terrain. Firefighters are working to keep the fire north of Forest Road 39N25; South of the Castle Crags Wilderness; East of Whalen Summit and West of the North Fork of Castle Creek. The fire is burning in steep, rugged terrain with seasonally dry and receptive fuel.
properties.title: Root Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
On September 1, 2025, the Rattlesnake Fire was reported on the Colville Reservation near Inchelium, WA. The fire - named Rattlesnake Fire- is burning in steep thick timber ground and grass sage steep within the old fire scar of the 2003 Rattlesnake Fire. 

Northwest Complex Incident Management Team 7 assumed command at 0600 on September 5th, 2025.

Evacuations orders: There are no evacuations. https://inciweb.wildfire.gov/incident-maps-gallery/wacoa-rattlesnake 

For updates regarding the Rattlesnake Fire, you can follow https://www.facebook.com/CCTBroadcasts on social media. Videos are available to those without Facebook accounts using that link.

Smoke Outlook: Air quality can change quickly. Know your risk to wildfire smoke and plan to reduce exposure. For current smoke reports visit https://fire.airnow.gov
properties.title: Rattlesnake

properties.field_incident_overview: The Ulm Creek Fire, located approximately 6 miles north of Little Guard Peak and approximately 5 miles east of Spion Kop on the ID/MT border. The fire is visible from Heron, Montana. It started on 8/30/2025 from abundant lightning that came through the region. It is burning in the Ulm Peak Fire scar from 2006. Initial attack efforts included district firefighters and engines, a Hotshot crew, and aviation support. Due to unseasonably warm and dry weather, the fire has exceeded initial attack efforts with the largest growth to date occurring between 9/2/2025 and 9/3/2025.
properties.title: Ulm Creek Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: Tacoma Creek Fire has been returned to the local district for management activities.  This page will no longer be updated.  For current information, please contact NEWICC at 509-685-6900.
properties.title: Tacoma Creek Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Green Mtn. Fire is located approximately eight miles west of Clark Fork, Idaho and three miles east of Kilroy Bay. The fire was discovered 8/29/2025 at 6:27pm. The fire is located just below Green Monarch Mountain on the upper 1/3 of the slope in difficult terrain overlooking Lake Pend Oreille. Aviation resources were assigned to the fire beginning on 8/30/2025.

Management of the Green Rattle Complex transitioned to the local Blue Team on September 19, 2025 at 6:00 a.m., led by Mitchell Prophet with Ryan Wagner serving as a trainee. Outgoing Northern Rockies Team 9 sincerely thanks the local community for their support and hospitality. The Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) over the complex has been lifted. The Green Rattle Complex is comprised of two fires which began on the Idaho Panhandle National Forests (IPNF) (Green Mtn. and Rattle Mountain) and two fires on the Kootenai National Forest (Spruce and Spruce Ridge).  

Dense, drift smoke from numerous fires in the Pacific Northwest, northern Rocky Mountains, and Canada has the potential to influence weather, as well as cause health hazards for the public. Check on https://www.airnow.gov/ to find out more about smoke and air quality advisories in your area.
properties.title: Green Mtn Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Log Fire started in the end of August after several days of thunderstorms passed over the Klamath National Forest. It is burning in a steep and remote area of the Marble Wilderness, about two miles northwest of English Peak. The difficult terrain and competition with other incidents for resources have hampered suppression efforts.

An emergency area closure is in place for the Log Fire, available here: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r05/klamath/alerts/log-fire-closure-order
properties.field_title_and_unit: CAKNF Log Fire Klamath National Forest
properties.title: Log Fire - Klamath National Forest

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Rattle Mountain Fire was first detected on Tuesday, September 2, 2025, burning adjacent to Rattle Mountain, north of FSR473. The Rattle Mountain Fire is located approximately thirteen miles north/northeast of Clark Fork, Idaho but is also visible from Troy, Montana. 

Management of the Green Rattle Complex transitioned to the local Blue Team on September 19, 2025 at 6:00 a.m., led by Mitchell Prophet with Ryan Wagner serving as a trainee. Outgoing Northern Rockies Team 9 sincerely thanks the local community for their support and hospitality. The Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) over the complex has been lifted.  The Green Rattle Complex is comprised of two fires which began on the Idaho Panhandle National Forests (IPNF) (Green Mtn. and Rattle Mountain) and two fires on the Kootenai National Forest (Spruce and Spruce Ridge).
properties.title: Rattle Mountain Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
Lower Sugarloaf Fire is a lightning-caused fire located near Sugarloaf Lookout. The fire is burning partially in the footprint of the 1994 Tyee Fire and the 2018 Cougar Creek Fire, as well as thick timber and brush that has not seen fire since records began being kept.  

Smoke is very visible to the communities of Plain, Leavenworth, Wenatchee, and Entiat.

Chelan County Sheriff’s Office has issued a Level 1 Evacuation Advisory (Stay Alert), Level 2 Evacuation Notice (Be Ready) and Level 3 Evacuation Alert (Go Now!)  for parts of the fire area, please visit http://bit.ly/4n63ZZF or https://www.co.chelan.wa.us/emer.../pages/active-emergencies for the latest evacuation information.

A Forest Service closure is also in effect around the fire area.  https://inciweb.wildfire.gov/incident-publication/waowf-lower-sugarloaf-fire/lower-sugarloaf-fire-area-forest-closure09-07-2025
properties.title: Lower Sugarloaf Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: The Labor Mountain Fire started on Monday, September 1st. It is burning between Standup and Stafford Creek drainages about 10 miles northeast of Cle Elum, WA. It is actively burning in very steep terrain in one of the drier areas on the Cle Elum Ranger District. The fire is burning in a popular recreation area, with many resources that are at risk, including 12 trailheads, recreation residences, Camp Wahoo and the Teanaway Community Forest and historic guard station. Public and fire fighter safety is the top priority.
properties.title: Labor Mountain Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: The Cedar Fire is being managed by California Interagency Incident Management Team 2 until Tuesday, September 9 at 0700.
properties.title: Cedar Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: On September 1, 2025, Snow Peak fire was reported in Ferry County, 19 miles west of Kettle Falls, WA. The fire is located in a remote area approximately 19 miles west of Kettle Falls, WA. The fire is burning in an inventoried roadless area with very difficult access by foot. Resources responding include crews, air attack, and helicopters. The Snow Peak cabin, a valuable recreation site in the alpine area NW of the fire, has been prepped with structure wrap and there have been past fuel treatments in the immediate vicinity of the cabin which significantly lowers the risk of impact.
properties.title: Snow Peak

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Timber Butte fire was reported on the afternoon of September 3rd at approximately 3:00 p.m. Burning in a remote area within the Hidden Pasture Creek Wilderness Area west of Dell, the fire was first reported as visible smoke near Little Water Canyon. Initial attack resources responded, and additional resources were ordered. The fire quickly grew, given the windy conditions associated with the passage of a dry cold front through the area. The fire was estimated at 1,062 acres by the evening hours and 2,245 acres by noon the next day. Given minimal fire behavior, the fire showed no measurable growth over subsequent days.

The fire is burning in steep, rocky terrain in a remote area; these conditions pose challenges to safe access, firefighting operations, and timely medical response if needed.

The fire is burning on lands managed by the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management. 

The cause of the fire is undetermined and is under investigation.
properties.title: Timber Butte

properties.field_incident_overview:
Management of the Green Rattle Complex transitioned to the local Blue Team on September 19, 2025 at 6:00 a.m., led by Mitchell Prophet with Ryan Wagner serving as a trainee. Outgoing Northern Rockies Team 9 sincerely thanks the local community for their support and hospitality. The Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) over the complex has been lifted. The Green Rattle Complex is comprised of the Green Mtn. and Rattle Mountain on the Idaho Panhandle National Forests (IPNF), and a fire on the Kootenai National Forest (Spruce). The Spruce and Spruce Ridge Fires merged on September 13 and is now called the Spruce Fire.

All of the fires are lightning-caused fires which began as the result of storms between Friday, August 29 and Monday, September 2.

The Green Mtn. Fire is located approximately eight miles west of Clark Fork, Idaho. The Rattle Mountain Fire is located approximately thirteen miles north/northeast of Clark Fork, Idaho but is also visible from Troy, Montana. The Spruce Fire is located approximately twelve miles southwest of Troy, Montana.

Green Mtn. Fire:  83 acres; 8% containment

Rattle Mountain Fire:  122 acres; 8% containment

Spruce Fire:  366 acres; 12% containment

TOTAL OVERALL CONTAINMENT: 10%

See the full road and trail closure descriptions on InciWeb, as well as the Idaho Panhandle National Forests and Kootenai National Forest websites: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r01/idahopanhandle/alerts, https://www.fs.usda.gov/r01/kootenai/alerts. A portion of the Green Mtn. Fire area is closed between Johnson Saddle and the FSR2706 intersection, including all roads and trails initiating/bisecting that area (FSR1063, as well as trails 68, 69, and 105). As long as fire activity allows, the Forest will keep FSR2706 open as an alternate route for FSR278; however, forest users are advised that FSR2706 is generally a narrower route, and high-clearance vehicles are advised. There is a separate road closure at FSR332 (Bunco Road), FSR258, FSR534, and FSR911 for timber activities and is unrelated to fire operations. A road closure on a portion of the FSR473 and FSR603 is in place in vicinity of the Spruce and Rattle Mountain fires. Please avoid the general area to allow access for firefighters and equipment.

Dense drift smoke from numerous fires in the Pacific Northwest and northern Rocky Mountains has the potential to influence weather, as well as cause health hazards for the public. Check on https://www.airnow.gov/ to find out more about smoke and air quality advisories in your area.
properties.title: Green Rattle Complex

properties.field_incident_overview: The Lynx Mountain Fire is burning 7 miles northwest of Inchelium and northeast of Twin Lakes.  Discovered on Sept. 2, hot, dry days contributed to significant initial fire growth.
properties.title: Lynx Mountain

properties.field_incident_description: Lightning-caused wildfire north of the Little Beaver drainage west of Ross Lake in North Cascades National Park Service Complex.
properties.field_incident_overview:
On August 27, following storms across the area, a lightning-caused fire was reported north of the Little Beaver drainage west of Ross Lake in North Cascades National Park Service Complex. 

Area, trail, and camp closures: Visitors should check the park Fire Closures page prior to a visit for up-to-date trail and camp closure information. Closures are in place to protect the public.
properties.title: Perry Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Marks Creek Fire was reported just after noon on September 2nd, burning in timber and brush approximately 18 miles east of Prineville, Oregon on Ochoco National Forest lands. Aggressive initial attack included engines, dozers, single engine super scoopers, helicopters, large air tankers, and other air and ground resources.

The Central Oregon Fire Management Service (COFMS) Type 3 Incident Management Team, Incident Commander Fore, assumed command of the fire the morning of September 3rd.  Operations focused on establishing and strengthening control lines. 

COFMS Type 3 Team transitioned command of the Marks Creek Fire to Oregon Department of Forestry's Complex Incident Management Team 2, Incident Commander Matt Howard at 6:00 p.m. on September 4th. Crews continue to focus operations on reinforcing containment lines, patrolling the perimeter for spot fires and slop overs, and working to construct fireline to limit fire growth.

ODF CIMT 2 transitioned command of the fire to the Prairie Division Type 4 organization from the Ochoco National Forest at 7:00 a.m. on September 12th. Crews will continue to work on suppression repair around the perimeter of the fire.
properties.title: Marks Creek

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Bridge Fire was reported on 9/3/2025 at 10:29 pm on the Malheur National Forest, within the Blue Mountain Ranger District. The fire is located approximately 9.9 miles northeast of Prairie City, near Dixie Lookout.

Fire crews are actively engaged in suppression efforts, with additional resources enroute to assist. The fire is burning in timber and brush within a steep, and roadless area. The cause of the fire is undetermined at this time. Due to the steep, rugged terrain in which the fire is located and the large amount of heavy, down and dead fuels present, the fire will remain on the landscape until a season ending event such as heavy rain or snow. Firefighters will work to limit the spread of the fire and protect values at risk while accounting for public and firefighter safety.

Motorists traveling along Highway 26 could see increased traffic and visible smoke, as firefighting operations continue.

For all evacuation information please go to:
Genasys Evacuation Map - https://protect.genasys.com/hazards/2001c3ee-af7d-4aa9-827a-232b150669fd?z=10.000105433629999&latlon=44.62346226723207%2C-118.62319026453702

For Closure information please go to:
Malheur National Forest | Bridge Fire Area Closure | Forest Service - https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/malheur/newsroom/releases/bridge-fire-area-closure-updated
properties.title: Bridge Fire - OR

properties.field_incident_description: Wildland Fire
properties.field_incident_overview:
Evacuations: On September 26, the Moon Complex experienced rapid fire growth, with long range spot fires and very active fire behavior. New evacuation orders were issued for areas downriver/southwest of the Moon Complex. On September 27, the evacuations were extended further to the south due to continued active fire behavior and growth. On September 29, evacuations were lowered from Level 3 (GO Now) to Level 2 (BE Ready) after rain fell on the fire and surrounding area.

Bear Camp Road/Forest Service Road 23 and Forest Service Road 2308 have been closed from Galice to Agness. Forest Service Road 33 has been closed from Agness to Powers. Eden Valley Road is closed.

The Rogue River has been closed from Grave Creek to Foster Bar. 

On September 3, a lightning event on the Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest caused a number of fires in the vicinity of the Rogue River about 10 miles northeast of Agness, Oregon. Six of these made up the initial Moon Complex: the Backbone, Brushy, Pinnacle, Tate, Paradise, and Stair fires. As of September 8, Paradise, Stair, and Brushy fires burned into the perimeters of other fires. Tate Fire is fully contained at 26 acres. Suppression work continued on the Backbone and Pinnacle fires. 

On September 26, the Backbone and Pinnacle fires merged, and will now be referred to as the Pinnacle Fire.

Fire Restrictions are in effect: Stage III fire restrictions went into effect on the Wild and Scenic Lower Rogue River on Friday, August 15, 2025. Building, maintaining, attending, or use of a fire is not permitted. To learn more, visit: https://www.fs.usda.gov/r06/rogue-siskiyou/alerts/stage-3-public-use-restrictions-wild-and-scenic-lower-rogue-river
properties.title: Moon Complex

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Kelsey Peak Fire is located 15 miles west of Glendale in the Lower Rogue River Corridor on Bureau of Land Management (BLM) Medford District administered lands. The Kelsey Peak Fire, along with numerous other fires, was sparked by passing thunderstorms on September 3, 2025. Initial attack by Oregon Department of Forestry’s (ODF) Southwest Oregon District was immediate. Despite aggressive firefighting tactics by local agencies over the next several days, the fire continued to grow.

Extended attack on the fire continued to challenge firefighters in steep, rugged terrain with persistent smoke halting air operations. ODF Complex Incident Management Team 1, Incident Commander Dan Quinones, was ordered on September 6 to manage suppression efforts on the Kelsey Peak Fire. Team 1 was in-briefed by ODF and BLM on Sunday, September 7, with transfer of command at 6:00 a.m. Monday, September 8.
properties.title: Kelsey Peak Fire

properties.field_incident_description: Black Rock Fire was reported on September 4, 2025 at 6:29pm.  The location was five miles north of Clarno, OR on the west side of the John Day River.
properties.field_incident_overview: Black Rock Fire was reported on September 4, 2025 at 6:29pm.  The location was five miles north of Clarno, OR on the west side of the John Day River.
properties.title: Black Rock Fire

properties.field_incident_description:
The fires occurred in steep terrain with heavy fuel loading with little to no road access. Suppression tactics were based on several safety concerns, including a lack of ingress and egress options that would result in unacceptable medevac times. Decisions are heavily based on firefighter safety and resources at risk. Resources continue to assess for opportunities for direct and indirect options.
A Type 3 Incident Commander has taken command of the fires. Crews and heavy equipment continue to prepare roads and trails to utilize as containment points if the fires continue to grow. There are currently no immediate concerns to private infrastructure. Smoke from the fires are visible along the Hwy 56 corridor.

A closure order is pending for roads and trails in the vicinity of the fires.
properties.field_incident_overview:
On August 31st, a lightning storm ignited 31 fires across the Kootenai National Forest.  Firefighting resources, (engines and hand crew modules) responded to these fires throughout the evening of Aug 31st and in the morning on September 1st. 10 lightning fires were ignited on the Cabinet Ranger District including the Isabella, Moran, and Lost Girl Fires which started in the Cabinet Mountain Wilderness.  Kootenai Rappelers were inserted into the Lost Girl fire on the evening of the August 31st.  Active fire behavior combined with difficult access and extremely steep and cliffy terrain compromised the safety of firefighters during this initial suppression efforts and firefighters disengaged ground operation.  A Type 3 Incident Commander has taken command of the fires. Crews and heavy equipment continue to prepare roads and trails to utilize as containment points if the fires continue to grow. There are currently no immediate concerns to private infrastructure. 

Isabella: Start Date: 09/01/2025; Size: 1,095 acres as of September 22, 2025

Lost Girl: Start Date: 08/31/2025; Size: 280 acres as of September 22, 2025

Moran Fire: Start Date: 08/31/2025; Size: .2 acres as of September 6, 2025 -The fire has not shown any smoke or heat for several days

*Updates will be made with any significant changes in fire behavior or growth. Updates may not occur daily.
properties.field_title_and_unit: MTKNF Isabella and Lost Girl Fires
properties.title: Isabella and Lost Girl Fires

properties.field_incident_description: The lightning-caused Foley Ridge Fire was reported on September 6 and is located on a cliff visible from Oregon Highway 242 (McKenzie Highway) approximately seven miles east of McKenzie Bridge.
properties.field_incident_overview: The lightning-caused Foley Ridge Fire was reported on September 6 and is located on a cliff visible from Oregon Highway 242 (McKenzie Highway) approximately seven miles east of McKenzie Bridge.
properties.title: Foley Ridge Fire

properties.field_incident_overview:
On September 6, 2025, USFS fire managers were able to assess a new fire start caused by lightning, named the Tunnel Creek Fire, located in a remote area of the Buckhorn Wilderness in Olympic National Forest.

The fire is roughly 10 miles west of Quilcene, Washington and 1.5 miles west of the Tunnel Creek Trailhead accessed from FS Road 2740.
properties.title: Tunnel Creek Fire

properties.field_incident_overview: Sheep Drive is a lightning-caused wildfire that was detected after a recent thunderstorm. This fire is in extremely steep, rugged, terrain making access difficult. There are no closures currently associated with this fire but the potential to impact FS Trail #505 is high.
properties.title: Sheep Drive

properties.field_incident_overview:
The Princess Fire started on September 29, 2025 in Polk County and was initially responded to by local fire departments. Texas A&M Forest Service was requested to provide assistance in the form of additional firefighters and heavy equipment at 1:30 pm and quickly responded. Texas A&M Forest Service is currently in unified command with local fire departments. Crews continue to construct containment lines around the outside of the fire with bulldozers. Aviation resources have been assigned to the fire. 

The fire started during a period of underlying dryness primarily in drought cured grass and timber fuels as warm and dry conditions continue to combined to produce a fire environment supportive of significant fire activity. 

There is a Temporary Flight Restriction (TFR) in place for the area over the Princess Fire [NOTAM: FDC 5/2543, https://tfr.faa.gov/tfr3/?page=detail_5_2543]. Please avoid the area to provide a safe environment for firefighting aircraft.
properties.title: Princess Fire
